title: BUN Creatinine Ratio
description: Evaluates kidney function by calculating the ratio of blood urea nitrogen (BUN) to serum creatinine, helping to distinguish between prerenal, intrinsic renal, and postrenal causes of kidney dysfunction.

parameters.name: bun
parameters.description: Blood urea nitrogen level in mg/dL

ranges.interpretation: Ratio <10 may suggest intrinsic renal disease, malnutrition, low protein intake, liver disease, or overhydration. Consider intrinsic kidney pathology such as acute tubular necrosis, glomerulonephritis, or interstitial nephritis.
Normal kidney function with appropriate filtration of both BUN and creatinine. This ratio indicates healthy renal physiology and adequate glomerular filtration rate.

Ratio >20 may indicate prerenal azotemia (dehydration, heart failure, shock), gastrointestinal bleeding, high protein intake, or postrenal obstruction. The kidneys are functioning but BUN is disproportionately elevated compared to creatinine.

references: Levey AS, Bosch JP, Lewis JB, Greene T, Rogers N, Roth D. A more accurate method to estimate glomerular filtration rate from serum creatinine: a new prediction equation. Modification of Diet in Renal Disease Study Group. Ann Intern Med. 1999;130(6):461-470.
National Kidney Foundation. K/DOQI clinical practice guidelines for chronic kidney disease: evaluation, classification, and stratification. Am J Kidney Dis. 2002;39(2 Suppl 1):S1-266.
Schrier RW. Diseases of the Kidney and Urinary Tract. 8th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins; 2007.
Brenner BM, Rector FC. Brenner and Rector's The Kidney. 9th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Saunders Elsevier; 2012.
notes: Normal serum creatinine range: 0.7-1.3 mg/dL (62-115 µmol/L)
Ratio should be interpreted in clinical context with other kidney function tests
High protein diet, GI bleeding, or certain medications can affect BUN levels
Muscle mass, age, and gender affect baseline creatinine levels
Use alongside eGFR and other renal function assessments for comprehensive evaluation
